title: Wednesday, 30th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

It's still August

PM11:02am

But there's a bit of second line news at least this morning

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Let's get on with a pic

PM11:02am

( CommentGoesHere -- sorry about tech issues. Be good to know if others are getting problems with Firefox.)

PM11:03am

Pic wise...

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I won't do David Tang, cos he's everywhere else

PM11:03am

But that is sad news

PM11:04am

So, instead...

11:04 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

John Browett

PM11:04am

Why can't this chap hold down a job?

11:04 am
PM11:05am

I mean, he looks cheery enough

PM11:05am

And, as we noted here just recently, he did a terrific job at Dixons

PM11:05am

Pretty much transformed customer service there

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Albeit temporarily

PM11:05am

Then he didn't last at Apple

PM11:06am

And didn't last at Monsoon (?)

11:06 am
PM11:06am

And now he's out at Dunelm after what? Less than two years?

BE11:06am

All of those have reasonable explanations, it can be argued.

BE11:06am

With Apple he was perhaps the wrong man for the job.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

hmm

BE11:07am

He was very much about delivery of numbers, cutting costs, squeezing pay and making the Genius Bar doofuses work harder.

PM11:07am

That was never going to go down well

11:07 am
BE11:08am

It wasn't really the Cupertino way, so he exited and they got Angela Ahrendts instead.

PM11:08am

And she doesnt mind the Genius Bar doofuses being doofuses...

BE11:09am

Indeed. She was a more. how can I phrase this? More of an aspirational appointment.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Dunelm statement here btw https://www.invest...1708300700042323P/

BE11:09am

She wasn't one to worry overly about refit spending inefficiencies and overtime rotas.

BE11:09am

As for Dunelm .... well, it's not Apple Stores, is it?

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Lots of sell side saying Buy Dunelm regardless

PM11:10am

But the stock's off pretty heavily

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 575.00, down 23 (-3.85%), High: 598.00, Low: 573.00, Volume: 470.96k
11:10 am
BE11:10am

The guidance from people close to soft furnishings is about some kind of personality clash .... which might be understandable.

BE11:11am

As Dunelm is deeply proud of its roots and its origin story. Literally rags to riches.

BE11:11am

Immediate effect, though.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

And so soon after the Worldstores acquisition, which moved Dunelm into hardlines.

BE11:12am

Let me get some of the aforermentioned sellside.

BE11:12am

Brief from Stifel.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The implication is that the decision relates to one of management style and the ability to
lead the executive team into the next stage of its development.
We believe the group continues to trade well, that WorldStores' integration is on track and
the Capital Markets Day is going ahead as planned.
An experienced management team led by Chairman Andy Harrison, Deputy Chairman
Will Adderley and Keith Down (CFO) will lead the group until a replacement is appointed.
The shares' trade at only a modest premium to the sector, on 12.5x FY18 P/E, and yield
c.4.5%.
Shareholders will get an opportunity to speak to management around the imminent final
results on September 13th. We believe the Capital Markets Day is still on track for October
11th.

BE11:13am

Less brief from Peel Hunt.

BE11:13am

Dunelm talks of the next phase of growth requiring different
leadership; we believe this is more about management style than John Browett’s
retail skill set. We can only gain encouragement that trading, the Worldstores
integration and the wider strategy are all on track and offer no cause for concern.
Indeed, the business looks to be in fairly good shape despite the subdued market
backdrop.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We were becoming increasingly positive on Dunelm, although had
yet to change recommendation or target price. Forecasts for FY2018 are looking
deliverable, with less chance of material forecast downside. With FY2017 final
results in September already a known quantity in profit terms, and Q1 trading
likely to outperform against weak comparatives, we then saw October’s Capital
Markets Day as an opportunity for a deep dive into Worldstores, which was
likely to firm up support for the shares and provide clarity on the profit potential
of the business over the next 3-4 years. Trading on a 2018E PER of 12.8x,
offering a 10% free cash flow yield and 5% dividend yield, with special
dividends likely to resume next year, we had seen Dunelm becoming a sector
outperformer in autumn. While the business benefits from a strengthened
leadership team, strong board and the presence of Will Adderley to steady the
ship, the uncertainty surrounding the future leadership of the business is likely to
weigh on the shares for now.

PM11:13am

Adderley family still control a bit chunk of this thing.

PM11:14am

Will Adderley -- the deputy chair -- son of Bill and Jean

11:14 am
BE11:14am

That's an important point. Will Adderley, the deputy chairman, is a deputy chairman in the same sense that Mike Ashley was deputy chairman of Sports Direct.

PM11:14am

hmm

PM11:14am

Sure he'll love that comparison

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Oof, yes, sorry. Not that I'm drawing a deeper parallel there. Just in terms of keeping a steady hand on the etc.

PM11:15am

Of course

BE11:15am

Let me move onto a buy note to make everyone forget I said that. UBS.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Dunelm states that trading in the first two months of the financial year has started
positively, with an encouraging LFL performance. Against a -4% comp in Q1 last year
this was to be expected, although given the September heatwave last year the best of
the weak comps in the quarter may just be arriving. Our FY18 PBT estimate is based on
2% LFL and 30bp gross margin dilution, the latter from the FY impact of the lower
gross margin WorldStores business.

BE11:16am

We set our PT under a DCF with an 8.5% WACC, 2% terminal sales growth and
12.5% terminal EBIT margin. If the WS business performs to plan, double running costs
drop out, and the market can show modest growth, then we believe Dunelm should be
able to show double-digit profit growth for the next few years.

undefined
11:16 am
PM11:17am

Footsie up a bit

PM11:17am

Brexit negotiations are a mess

PM11:17am

North Korea still nuts

11:17 am
PM11:17am

ICOs everywhere

PM11:17am

Guess we look at some of these second line trading statements then

PM11:17am

Or do you have other stuff you want to discuss Bryce?

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Hmmmmmmm it's kinda quiet again, unless I'm missing crucial stuff.

PM11:18am

Can I ask you about Canakinumab?

PM11:19am

So, I was duty editing on Monday -- and this wonder drug stuff had been in the papers over the weekend

11:19 am
PM11:19am

And the FT hadn't covered

BE11:19am

Um, I guess so. That's Novartis's one, right?

PM11:19am

And I'm wondering -- damn, have we missed a major medical breakthrough

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Like the Daily Mail says?

BE11:20am

No. No we haven't.

PM11:20am

Best heart drug since statins: New injection could save thousands of lives by preventing heart attacks and also slash cancer risk

Read more: http://www.dailyma...html#ixzz4rETwXtLC
Follow us: @MailOnline on Twitter | DailyMail on Facebook

11:20 am
PM11:20am

So I checked Novartis share price on Monday and decided not to follow

BE11:21am

The Phase III combo data presented to the ESC showed a 15% reduction in heart stuff, which was ahead of a Q4 filing.

BE11:21am

Which is nice. But it's combo data, as in it's incremental benefit to standard therapy.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

There was something in the results where it actually did slash lung cancer deaths, but they didn't understand how or why -- i think

BE11:22am

Yeah, the cancer stuff is interesting rather than significant -- yet.

PM11:23am

Novartis stock basically unchanged since this study came out, tw

11:23 am
BE11:23am

The data show it to be quite useful for patients who've already had a heart attack and have inflammatory atherosclerosis. But not great.

BE11:23am

This stuff costs $200,000 a year, by the way. At least it does in the US.

PM11:23am

Oh

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And the NEJM found it to have "no observed effect on cardiovascular mortality"

PM11:24am

I suppose that helps cut the bill

BE11:24am

The cancer stuff came out of a subsequent investor call, not a proper presentation.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Lower risk of cancer mortality versus placebo, Novartis says. But we literally don't know a single thing beyond that bald statement.

BE11:25am

Here's Credit Suisse.

BE11:25am

Lower CV sales offset by new cancer revenues: We have lowered our canakinumab peak sales in CV risk from $1,500m to $600m (based on a 10% penetration by 2022 of an annual cohort of 350,000 patients at a price of $10,000, and assuming that 80% patients once started on the drug, remain for at least a year for a year winding down to around 20% remaining on the drug at 5 years). This change is offset by adding $1bn peak sales potential at 25% probability of success in oncology following the compelling data on reduced cancer incidence. We make negligible changes to our forecasts, increasing Core EPS (2017-21) by an average 0.4%.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

One in four chance of success in oncology looks wildly optimistic, but it's a handy offset for the fan charts.

BE11:26am

(@Mouselet: deflation + 2022)

PM11:27am

Mouselet -- they are making assumptions on future price if/when it goes mass market

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Currently the drug is priced at c $200,000 a year in the rare indications for which it has approval

PM11:28am

So -- to recap, this was just a story flammed up by the British press on a bank holiday weekend.

BE11:28am

Yes. Most of the proper work we have for canakinumab is related to gout, I think. But that's a vague memory.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Lowest common denominator media

PM11:28am

And we wonder why we get the political leaders we have

PM11:29am

(Sorry)

11:29 am
undefined
PM11:30am

WH Smith still smugly fleecing people at airports I see

PM11:30am

Pre close update here https://www.invest...1708300700022192P/

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Yep -- having tested my knowledge of monoclonal antibodies with no warning whatsoever, WH Smith provides a sedate re-entry to the UK market.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,856, up 7 (+0.38%), High: 1,864, Low: 1,845, Volume: 98.75k
BE11:31am

It's the usual story.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Travel doing well, high street still in a desperate race to find things to sell.

BE11:32am

Shares at an all-time high where all other retailers are around 12 month lows.

BE11:32am

Why? Because investors trust far too much in the captive consumer franchise system.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

WH Smith can keep what appears to be an unofficial and unspoken non-competition rule with Relay and remain the only place to buy a paperback at the airport.

BE11:34am

It can keep bidding up franchise pitches on the certainty that the cost will be offset by price gouging.

BE11:34am

Nothing can go wrong here!

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:34am

Just as nothing went wrong for Restaurant Group.

BE11:35am

Which did exactly the same in the cinemas and the food franchises at airports, then discovered irrational competition and a race to cannibalise space and all its earnings disappeared.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Anyway, as it stands the sector's carved up by WH Smith and its rahter-too-close sister company SSP.

BE11:36am

Does the consumer benefit from the franchise system they're successfully exploiting? Of course not.

PM11:37am

Why are so many other countries allowing themselves to be infected in the same way?

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Smiths gone or going into Germany, Spain, Italy and Singapore now

PM11:37am

Airport wise

BE11:38am

It's a very good model for all parties. Competitive tendering, upfront fees and gradual bond-like payback on overpriced Toblerones.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Anyway, here comes an analyst to tell you that price gouging is good for shareholders.

BE11:39am

JP Morgan will do.

BE11:39am

WH Smith just reported a confident FY17 pre-close trading update, confirming that FY results should be ‘in line
with expectations’. Management noted that both divisions are on track with plans, with Travel continuing to
grow strongly, both domestically and internationally, and High Street continuing to deliver on profitability
enhancements. In all, we would expect Consensus to remain largely unchanged following this in-line update.
The stock has been strong in the last few weeks, hitting all-time highs last week, and no changes to estimates at
this stage might trigger some profit taking first thing this morning. Still, with solid performance sustained across
the Group, we continue to like WH Smith within UK retail and retain our Overweight recommendation.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Solid update on Travel, noting that the division continued to deliver a ‘strong performance with good sales
across all of our channels’. WH Smith also flagged in the release that the new store programme is progressing
in line with plans both in the UK and internationally with three new openings in Italy (Rome Fiumicino and
Ciampino, as well as Turin; this a new win) As a reminder, WH Smith had previously guided for +2% LFL in
H2, including +5% in Q3, which should be achievable in our view given the confident comments today. On
the High Street division, management just flagged that it continues to perform in line with expectations (recall
the company had guided for LFL at -4% in H2 following -3% in H1 and -4% in Q3).

BE11:39am

All on track on profitability improvements. In line with the comments at the time of the 14-week trading
update at the beginning of June, WH Smith noted that the profit performance of the High Street division is in
line with expectations as the company “cost savings and margin improvements have been delivered in line
with our profit focused strategy”. We expect the Travel division to also have continued to deliver profitability
improvements thanks to ongoing GM expansion (JPMe: +90bps both in H2 and in FY17). As a reminder, in
FY17e we are looking for Travel EBIT up 9% to £95m, or EBIT margin up slightly to 15.2%, and for High
Street EBIT flat at £62m, implying an EBIT margin up 50bps to 10.2%. We leave our FY17e PBT estimate
unchanged at £138m.

BE11:40am

And Barclays.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Valuation undemanding given Travel upside potential: Although the High Street
division continues to deter many investors, the track record of delivering free cash flow
from this mature business continues to be impressive. We also expect stronger growth
rates in Travel over our forecast period such that both the forecast mix and our Sum of
the Parts valuation will increasingly derive from Travel. In FY17, we estimate c60% of
EBIT will be from Travel vs 68% of the EV at our £19.90 Price Target. We expect FY18 to
be another year of progress and forecast 4% group EBIT growth, which when combined
with a £50m share buyback, creates 6% EPS and DPS growth (2.7% yield). The shares
remain our Top Pick and we reiterate our OW rating.

undefined
BE11:42am

What else? We've lost the ROTR to ..... uh, god knows what.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

hehehe

PM11:42am

We sure have

BE11:42am

Maybe the FTSE rejig? There's always the FTSE rejg!

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Rejig away

BE11:43am

Excitingly! Royal Mail might be out!

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 390.50, up 3 (+0.77%), High: 393.80, Low: 389.00, Volume: 659.46k
11:43 am
BE11:43am

But the numbers are stupidly tight.

BE11:44am

My data suggest Royal Mail finished 111th in the all share by market cap.

PM11:44am

(wayneJ -- sorry! will do so straight after this session)

11:45 am
PM11:45am

What's gone and/or coming in for sure?

BE11:45am

NMC in, Provident out. We know that.

BE11:46am

But then, any stock at 111th or lower can be deleted. But it's optional and if FTSE's share count data are different from mine it could well survive.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Berkeley will be up if Royal Mail goes down.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,698, down 24 (-0.64%), High: 3,745, Low: 3,697, Volume: 134.11k
BE11:47am

In terms of the FTSE 250, worth watching Alfa.

11:47 am
Alfa Financial Software Holdings PLC (ALFA:LSE): Last: 434.00, up 3.25 (+0.75%), High: 434.00, Low: 430.25, Volume: 5.69k
BE11:48am

Which is very underowned, having only recently floated, and will require about 36 days of volume to get the trackers up to weight.

BE11:48am

Most of which will be pre-positioned, though you can't always rely on that.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

This is software for asset finance, yeah?

PM11:49am

Airplanes and stuff -- not bonds and stocks

BE11:49am

Sort of, yes,

11:49 am
BE11:49am

And that ends today's FTSE rejig bulletin. Back next quarter.

PM11:49am

It's got a really irritating website https://www.alfasystems.com/product

undefined
11:49 am
PM11:50am

So I clicked wayneJ nuclear fusion link

PM11:50am

Sheesh

PM11:50am

We need to find something else for the next 10 mins

11:50 am
BE11:51am

....................................... yes. And particle physics is probably outside our remit.

BE11:51am

Petrofac requested repeatedly. That'll do.

Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 427.20, up 4 (+0.95%), High: 451.60, Low: 418.00, Volume: 2.44m
11:51 am
BE11:51am

What's become a familiar story.

BE11:52am

Operationally, it's fine. Still. Pretty much.

BE11:52am

(@REF: thanks for the correction. I would've clicked on the link if I had at least 16 more hours in the day.)

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Investigation overhangs like a sword of whatever, but for the moment Petrofac ticks along.

BE11:53am

Here comes Barclays.

BE11:53am

Petrofac’s 1H17 results showed a company focused on the reality of a smaller, asset-light business, with operational performance key to any delivery. EBITDA of US$323mn was in-line with our estimates and 10% ahead of IBES consensus. Backlog fell to US$12.5bn, excluding the recent US$1bn award in Oman and tendering activity remains high. Net debt increased to US$1bn, optically a big jump from the start of the year (US$600mn) but that came in surprisingly low. The underlying increase, we estimate to be closer to US$100mn in the half. Going forward, the company appears focused on reducing net debt and, as a start, has cut its dividend by 42%, which combined with lower capital requirements release around US$200mn of additional cash. With no update on on-going investigations, we see little to add to the pervading negative sentiment surrounding the stock and see results as slightly positive.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

And Jefferies.

BE11:54am

Conclusion: Revenue decline, further IES charges & reduced dividend are reality check
events that we feel are largely captured in our valuation.
Details: Reported 1H17 net profit $70m misses cons $129m & JEFe $141m due to $88m
charges (Greater Stella). Adj net profit of $158m is however an 11% beat to cons $142m
(JEFe $141m) and EBITDA of $323m at 10.1% also beats cons $296m at 8.5% mainly
as revenue is lower at $3,126m vs. $3,468m cons. A reduced dividend of 12.7cts (down
from 22cts) vs. cons flat dividend y/y (JEFe carry a zero dividend as we cut to conserve cash
in our upgrade post the SFO fall). Order intake of $2.7bn ytd ($2.4bn in E&C) and "well
placed on a number of bids" means our YE18 revenues of $5.7bn (vs. cons $6.4bn) look
ok. Net debt of $1.0bn, "good liquidity of $1.3bn" and refinancing of $300m term loans
maturing in Aug 17 for up to 2yrs (and reduced div) reduces some balance sheet pressure.
Presentation at 9:30am UK time and webcast live on PFC website.

BE11:55am

And MOST.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

We expect the market to focus on the dividend cut in the
results. 1H17 interim dividend of 12.7 US Cents was 42% lower than 1H16 where
consensus was, reflecting analyst's confidence in the dividend commitment and
27% below MSe with a greater cut than we anticipated (we wrote on dividend cut
to preserve liquidity here). Management states that the action is to focus on net
debt reduction and setting a sustainable dividend level given current market
conditions. The company guides that it will aim for 2-3x dividend cover going
forward, and the interim dividend will continue to represent ⅓ of FY dividend.
That implies DPS of $0.38 for FY17 down from $0.66 in FY16 and consensus FY17
of $0.57.

BE11:56am

FY17 guidance remains vague and concerns over the
SFO continue to dominate. Stay Equal-weight.

BE11:56am

That's the upshot.

11:56 am
undefined
PM11:56am

Shall I finish with some Brexit grey?

PM11:56am

GIven the sky outside

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Let me just hoof in an Ocado buy note first, for old time's sake.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 303.90, up 12.3 (+4.22%), High: 305.10, Low: 297.50, Volume: 1.24m
PM11:57am

Oh sure

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Citi's had a look and arrived at a 400p target.

PM11:58am

Well done Citi

BE11:59am

[W]e believe its end-to-end automated warehouse solution leaves it well placed to be a leading solutions provider in the $5.6tn global grocery market.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

To be clear, this was published this morning. Not in 2005, this morning.

BE11:59am

The channel shift in
retail is well under way. Grocery has lagged – with complexity and challenging
economics damping supply – but penetration is already 5-10% in the lead countries
and with WMT, KR and AMZN increasing supply in North America (USA less than 2% pen.).

PM11:59am

$5.6tn global grocery market. yeah right

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And it's the thesis of robot warehouses being cheaper than meat-based labour units. As seen recently from .... Credit Suisse was it?

BE12:00pm

Better
freshness, availability and range all contribute to a superior customer experience,
but we view the low-cost profile of Ocado’s automated CFCs as its key attribute.
Ocado’s FY16 “store” EBITDA margins were 10.1%, with its second-generation
‘Hive’ warehouses targeting c.11.5% margins and an order pick time of 5-10 mins.

BE12:00pm

We estimate Ocado will carry £37m cost (c.3% sales) and invest £60m R&D capex
in FY17 as it develops a universal solution to fulfil broadlines retailing. We estimate
robotic picking alone would add c.200bps of margin with a less than 1yr pay back on capex

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

While ‘costplus’, store-based fulfilment presently prevails, we expect the development of better
& cheaper technologies to increase automation throughout the grocery value chain.

BE12:01pm

Our 400p SOTP-based TP comprises (1)
311p for its UK ops (1.4x EV/sales) incl. Gp. net debt and a 103p drag from R&D,
and (2) 89p for its nascent international ops, with one agreement signed to date.

BE12:01pm

The best thing I've read on Ocado this year is Exane's coverage.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Which I did my damnedest to summarise here: https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

PM12:03pm

That note did real damage on the day

BE12:03pm

The brave new world talked about elsewhere of autonomous delivery vans carting groceries collected by robot claws in an unmanned warehouse remains theoretical.

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

Meanwhile, a company like Amazon has how many employees on it's books? 290k?

BE12:04pm

Yep, Amazon has gone for the meat-based solution.

BE12:05pm

And at Ocado, for the moment, you have a lot of capex sinking into an unproven robot model, on top of which lives a sales force that has taken around a decade to get its first customer.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

A decade and counting, I should say.

PM12:05pm

hehehe

BE12:05pm

Anyway, that's our semi-regular kick at Ocado done.

12:05 pm
undefined
PM12:05pm

We're over time!

BE12:06pm

Sure are. Bit of Brexit grey then leave the reader in peace?

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Er, can do yes

PM12:06pm

Malcolm Barr's sub title just caught me eye..

PM12:07pm

The longer the UK resists a commitment on financial legacy issues, the less ability it will have to shape the transition arrangement

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

This is so obviously the case it makes you want to scream

PM12:07pm

I'll just throw up the grey

PM12:07pm

Rhetoric from both the UK and EU sides around the third round of negotiations on Brexit suggests both sides are digging in to their positions: the UK insisting that future trade issues and the financial settlement must be discussed together, the EU insisting that a clearer commitment from the UK on legacy financial issues must be forthcoming before talks on trade can begin. Difficult issues on Ireland also remain, although our sense is that there would be tolerance to move ahead with the talks and deal with these at a later stage. On the rights of EU-UK citizens there are also significant disagreements but, in our view, these would also not prevent moving to the second phase of the talks. Remember that in all three spaces the EU has given itself the space to determine what “sufficient progress” to move to the next stage means.

According to today’s Times newspaper, Theresa May will “go over the heads” of the commission negotiators and lobby EU leaders directly for talks to move on to the next stage at the EU Council meeting in late October. The newspaper reports that some ministers believe the Commission is repeating what it did during negotiations with Greece, where it prevented Greece from negotiating directly with more sympathetic countries. In our view, such a strategy on the UK’s part belies a great deal of misunderstanding of how the EU has worked and continues to work.

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

As Yanis Varoufakis’ book on the Greek crisis reports, the Commission was often among those most sympathetic to the Greek position and keenest to broker agreement. It was German dominance of the Eurogroup, and the inability of PM Tsipras to change the German position via direct appeals to Merkel, that boxed the Greeks in. As Varoufakis also recounts, there were numerous private indications of sympathy with the Greek position from other EU countries that amounted to little when it came to the crunch of negotiations in the Eurogroup. We do not see any meaningful signs that the Franco-German position on Brexit is set to change significantly at this point, nor that the EU Council will do anything to undermine the role of those who it has empowered to negotiate on its behalf. In the same manner that Merkel repeatedly directed Tsipras back to negotiations in the Eurogroup, we expect the Council will refer PM May back to negotiations with the Commission.

Today’s Guardian newspaper reports the results of polling by ICM which suggests that while public acceptance of some form of EU “exit fee” is rising, it remains a difficult sell for UK politicians. Back in April, 15% of those polled believed a £10bn payment would be acceptable. As of August, 41% of those polled regard £10bn as acceptable (40% deem it unacceptable). Terminology such as “exit fee” undoubtedly influences these responses. But responses to any “fee” above £10bn are uniformly negative. Although we expect the UK position to begin to soften once the Conservative party conference in early October has passed, the potential for the issue to delay progress in the talks is clear.

PM12:07pm

So what is the implication if the talks are stalled for a number of weeks or even months? Some argue that, given the amount of issues which need to be dealt with and the proximity of the March 2019 date, this raises the possibility of an ‘accidental’ Brexit, wherein disruption ensues simply because there is not sufficient time to conclude a coherent withdrawal agreement. We don’t see it that way – simply because the March 2019 date is movable. If a workable agreement is in reach, our expectation is that unanimous agreement to move the March 2019 date would be forthcoming. Moreover, the transition arrangement that the EU appears to have in mind is one which seeks to extend the status quo while removing the UK’s voting rights. By replicating the status quo across the board, there is no need for detailed transitional arrangements at the sectoral level. The main implication of the ‘stalling’ of the talks at this stage is that it reduces the time available for the transition to be made ‘bespoke’ to UK needs, and increases the likelihood of a “copy and paste” and existing arrangements.

A significant lingering question is how the legal basis for the transitional agreement will be provided. This is an issue we have raised several times in the past, and yesterday’s Daily Telegraph ran a story highlighting some of the issues. The Telegraph’s spin was that legal issues may serve to mean the transitional agreement has to be limited to just 2 years. An alternative view is that Article 50 withdrawal agreement, agreed via qualified majority vote, is not a strong enough legal basis to set up the transitional period (as it is meant predominantly to deal with legacy withdrawal issues) . As a result, a separate Treaty between the UK and the EU will be needed to establish the transitional arrangement – which means unanimity of support among EU nations will be required. Dr Richard North explains some of the legal issues around this here. We are not lawyers and hence cannot claim any definitive legal view on the issue. We do note however that the 6 months Barnier has always said is necessary for ratification of the withdrawal agreement appears a rather leisurely time frame if that agreement is not a treaty in its own right and is ratified via a single vote in the European Parliament and QMV. That time frame has always struck us as more consistent with a separate withdrawal Treaty.

PM12:08pm

The potential need for the transitional agreement to take the form of separate Treaty with unanimous agreement serves to further compress the time available to the UK to negotiate its form, and creates both political and legal hurdles to changing arrangements from the status quo during the transition period. In our view, the lack of detailed and workable proposals in the position papers the UK has produced, and the failure to advance the talks owing to the disagreement over money, mean that that the UK is losing the limited ability it had to shape the transitional arrangements to accommodate its policy objectives.
